sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• Heart failure, chronic: Initial, 5 mg ORALLY twice daily; after 2 weeks, adjust based on heart rate; for resting rate greater than 60 beats per minute (bpm), increase dose by 2.5 mg twice daily; for 50 to 60 bpm, continue current dose; for less than 50 bpm or for signs or symptoms of bradycardia, decrease dose by 2.5 mg twice daily; MAX dose, 7.5 mg twice daily
  • Stable angina, chronic, In combination with beta-blocker therapy: 5 mg ORALLY twice daily for 2 months, then increase to 7.5 mg ORALLY twice daily if heart rate is at least 50 beats per minute; used in combination with atenolol 50 mg ORALLY once daily (study dosing)

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono: Safety and efficacy not established in pediatric patients

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• Renal impairment, CrCl greater than 15 mL/min: No adjustment required
  • Hepatic impairment, mild to moderate (Child-Pugh A and B): No adjustment required
  • Hepatic impairment, severe (Child-Pugh C): Use contraindicated
  • History of conduction defects or bradycardia that could lead to hemodynamic compromise: Initiate at 2.5 mg orally twice daily and titrate based on heart rate.

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
Heart failure, chronic
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
Stable angina, chronic, In combination with beta-blocker therapy

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• Acute decompensated heart failure
  • Concomitant use with strong CYP3A4 inhibitors
  • Pacemaker dependent
  • Resting heart rate below 60 beats per minute before treatment
  • Severe hepatic impairment
  • Severe hypotension (less than 90/50 mmHg)
  • Sick sinus syndrome, sinoatrial block, or third-degree atrioventricular block, except in presence of functioning demand pacemaker

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Cardiovascular:
  • -- Avoid use with second-degree AV block in patients without a functioning demand pacemaker
  • -- Use not recommended in patients with demand pacemakers set to 60 or greater beats per minutes
  • -- Increased risk of atrial fibrillation; monitoring recommended; discontinue use if develops
  • -- Bradycardia has been reported; increased risk with sinus node dysfunction, conduction defects, ventricular dyssynchrony; monitoring recommended if used with other negative chronotropic agents
  • -- Sinus arrest and heart block have been reported
  • Reproductive:
  • -- Appropriate contraception is required with use in women of childbearing potential
  • Concomitant use:
  • -- Avoid use with verapamil or diltiazem
  • -- Avoid use with CYP3A4 inducers or moderate CYP3A4 inhibitors

sub.title: Pregnancy Category
sub.mono: Fetal risk cannot be ruled out. (TH)

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Ivabradine reduces spontaneous pacemaker activity at the cardiac sinus node by blocking the hyperpolarization-activated cyclic nucleotide-gated (HCN) channel to selectively inhibit I(f)-current, thus reducing the heart rate. Ventricular repolarization and myocardial contractility are not affected.

sub.title: Absorption
sub.mono:
• Tmax, oral: 1 hour
  • Bioavailability, oral: 40%
  • Effect of food: Absorption delayed 1 hour; exposure increased 20% to 40%

sub.title: Metabolism
sub.mono:
• Intestines: Extensive, via CYP3A4-mediated oxidation
  • Liver: Extensive, via CYP3A4-mediated oxidation
  • N-desmethylated derivative (S 18982): Major, active
  • Substrate of CYP3A4

sub.title: Excretion
sub.mono:
• Fecal: Some excretion of metabolites
  • Renal: 4%, unchanged
  • Renal clearance: 4.2 L/hr
  • Total body clearance: 24 L/hr

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Advise patient to report symptoms of bradycardia or atrial fibrillation.
  • Recommend female patient avoid pregnancy during therapy.
  • Warn patient to avoid driving or other activities where sudden changes in light intensity may occur until drug effects are realized, due to potential for luminous phenomena (phosphenes).
  • Instruct patient to take drug with food to increase absorption.
  • Counsel patient to avoid grapefruit juice.
